I am a 40-year-old with Autism. Speaking from experience, most of the 40, 50, and 60 year-olds with autism were never diagnosed. Additionally, those who are "high-functioning" can repeatedly be misdiagnosed: depression, bipolar, OCD, and ADD are some of the more common misdiagnoses. We are right next to you, but until we suffer a serious setback, our ASD status isn't noticed.

I, personally, am tired of being "weird." Perhaps the upcoming wave of autistics isn't such a bad thing: when all of us are weird, none will be.

Andy,

The 'Climate Change Communications Crowd' seem to be doing exactly what Olson relates in his blog piece -- they are 'buffing a turd'. They have a shaky theory, badly analyzed questionable data, and wild, unsupportable predictions which don't turn out to be true.

They have to get back to scientific basics -- re-check or re-formulate their hypothesis, design experiments that would invalidate it or support it, do those experiments with real honest data that have been checked and rechecked for bias, accept the results of those experiments (instead of fudging the results to support their desired outcome), use those honest results to adjust their hypothesis. In other words, real science.

There are so many questionable 'priors' being accepted without inspection that the current crop of climate studies are all likely to be wrong. We have seen this happen in medical science when researchers have published faked results, sending subsequent researchers chasing butterflies for years, before they realize what has happened and all have to retract their work.

Bad science has been defended and covered up. Misconduct condoned. The system fiddled with and rigged. Data and methods withheld.

The problem, as I see it, is that Olson's 'general public' simply recognizes a 'turd' when they see it....and no amount of 'buffing that turd' is going to make it any more acceptable.

Dale McIntrye post #32.

In defense of Susan Anderson and in contrast to your post, it’s all about how you massage the data to arrive at your conclusions, right? If you take the Hadcrut3v data set and average out the temperature anomalies for the decade 1990 – 1999 and compare that with the average for 2000- 2010 you’ll find that this past decade averaged roughly .170 degrees C warmer than the previous one. That would mean a trend of roughly 1.7 degrees C per century in sharp contrast to your negative value. Here’s the data set if you have the time to do the math. http://tinyurl.com/ya94gcc I didn’t need Lucia to help me, it’s pretty basic stuff.

I also looked at the UAH satellite data, not exactly a hotbed for AGW alarmism and find it hard to see a cooling trend there. But then I realize I don’t always see the world the way others view it.

There is reason for tiger enthusiasts to celebrate: India's wild tiger population has grown 12 per cent in the last four years.

According to the 2010 tiger census, whose results were declared on Monday, there are approximately 1,706 of the big cats in the country, which includes about 70 in the marshes of the Sunderbans, which have never been scientifically surveyed before. The 2006 census had estimated that there were 1,411 tigers, without including any from the Sunderbans.

Thirty per cent of the tiger population lives in areas outside the government's reserves, giving conservationists a new challenge in the effort to protect them.

The celebrations, however, were muted by the decrease in land area where tigers can thrive. “Tiger occupancy areas shrunk from 9 million hectares to less than 7.5 million hectares over the last four years,” said Environment and Forests Minister Jairam Ramesh. “This means that tiger corridors are under severe threat, especially in central India…in Madhya Pradesh and northern Andhra Pradesh.”

Not surprisingly, these are the two States that have fared the worst in the census, with tiger populations falling to 213 in Madhya Pradesh and 65 in Andhra Pradesh.

Successful efforts

The largest number of tigers lives in Karnataka – about 280 – and conservation efforts have been successful in the entire Western Ghats area, with Tamil Nadu and Kerala also seeing good results. The Terai belt of grasslands at the Himalayan foothills in Uttarakhand have also done surprisingly well in nurturing their tiger populations.

While Kaziranga in Assam has 100 tigers, the largest in a single reserve, there are worrying signs from the North Eastern area. These forested hills are capable of supporting far more than the number of tigers that were found in the area, but poaching and the pressure of developmental activities have kept the numbers low.

Planning Commission deputy chairman Montek Singh Ahluwalia and Water Resources Minister Salman Khursheed flanked Mr. Ramesh as he announced the census results.

Developmental issue

Of particular note is the fact that they do a minimal amount of mandatory testing, The issuance of trust is a top down model where society in general, along with government officials, and educational administrators trust the teachers to do an effective job, and the teachers, in turn, trust their students to hold themselves accountable for their own progress in learning,  How about that? Trust that leads to learning for the sake of learning.  Contrast this to NCLB and the rampant corruption of school administrators and some teachers to game the system. So it's not a world record...just a record time in the world's best marathon?
Boston's a city of champions and who cares what anyone else thinks?

Having run Boston 5 times, many years ago, and having finished 128th once in NYC and 34th in Chicago, a flat course, also many years ago, and run a 2:31 in NYC at age 40, again many years ago, I can say Boston is the easiest marathon I ever ran.  Heartbreak Hill is a joke.  The combination of cool temperature, supporting crowd, overall downhill, really relatively small hills beginning at about mile 18, pretty good water service, and the last six miles all downhill make it a good "tune-up" for more difficult marathons in warmer weather and more difficult terrain later in the year.  It is even easier than flat courses, which sap strength from constant repetitive strides.  A strong tail wind as occurred this year would only add to its advantages.  Because of the reasons I have stated and others, no world record should ever be claimed there, or probably anywhere.

Your article of April 18 by Peter May "Kenyan Runs Fastest Marathon in Boston" made it sound like Boston is a point-to-point course:

"I.A.A.F. rules state that marathon records must be set on what is considered a loop course instead of a point-to-point course, meaning that the starting and finish lines cannot be farther apart than 50 percent of the race distance, or 13.1 miles. The Boston course starts in Hopkinton, Mass., 26.2 miles from the finish."

A 2.03 is indeed a first that shaves of almost 50 seconds of the current world record. Its a tragedy but there is a valid reason for this not being counted as world record. In the world of highly competitive runners, tail winds and course gradients do matter and can provide just that extra bit to shave off a few seconds.

Besides the ace runners, every runner was a winner. I just read about a long time severe refractory asthma patient who ran the boston marathon for the 4th time today and completed it in 7 hrs!

These are the real heroes. Or the PowerTeam of several myeloma patients who ran the marathon as well today. Including one person who has received more than 20 chemo sessions! Hats off to these runners.

Boston is not normally an easy course- never mind the rule re: net downhill.  Starting at mile 16 you begin to ascend the four famous Newton hills- culminating in the famous" Heartbreak" which peaks just before mile 21.  The relatively slow times of Boston's modern day winners when compared to other faster courses like London and Berlin reflect this handicap.  Today's winds simply neutralised the effect of those uphills and put it on a closer footing with the other courses- the difference being the downhills today made it only "slightly" faster.

There is something strange about the elite men's times, beyond the nature of the course and the tailwind.  After all, this course has been run for many years, by world class runners, and now in the last two years the course record has come down by about 5 minutes?  While Gebrselassie's world record of 2:03:59 makes much sense, given his career, Gebrsellassie is about a minute faster than any other world class marathoner had run until today, and then to have Mutai lower it by 57 seconds?  Very hard to believe.  I will be interested to see further analysis of this, particularly if anyone speaks to the last time the Boston course was rigorously checked for distance, whether there have been any changes in the last two years.

With all this international notoriety the Boston Marathon receives, it appears highly disadvantageous for this governing body to still turn a blind eye to the race's victor. "Technicalities and inconsistencies, it seems, are always strange partners in the sport of track and field.", notwithstanding [this] hearkens one to the abysmal condition of America's course, as well. Should the governing body acquiesce or rule with a righteous hand? To re-instill an understanding regarding a basic humanity lost, or misplaced beforehand, and reinvigorate an American spirit almost permanently lost less than one decade ago? ‘Tis a sad tale to ponder…

I would like to know how the original marathon - the one run by Pheidippides in 490 BC. - compares in dificulty to the modern marathons, which are often run on flat routes that favor faster times.  In other words, has the degree of difficulty been reduced to accomodate faster times, notwithstanding that the athletes may also be better.

Anyone who watched this year's Boston Marathon knows that it was one of the sport's finest hours, world record or not. There is no doubt that the near-perfect conditions allowed Geoffrey Mutai to run the fastest marathon ever. But what makes the Boston Marathon so special is not the possibility of a world records, but the epic battles that play out year after year over an historic course. In that regard, today's race was a triumph for the sport.

Mutai, Ryan Hall, Desi Davila and countless other amazing athletes gave everyone who watched this year's race a memory that will last a lifetime. Hall and Davila showed us that Americans can run with (and challenge) the best Kenyans and Ethiopian runners in the world. And the way these races played out (with drama from the gun) showed that non-rabbited races are exponentially more interesting than races led by pacesetters for 18 miles.

In short, you're wrong to say that weather didn't play a factor in today's fast times, but you're also wrong to think that it matters. Kudos to race director Dave McGillivray and everyone who ran for giving us a race for the ages.

What a confusing article.From the misstatement that "Mutai’s time does not count as a world record because the Boston course is not a point-to-point race" (when of course it is a point-to-point race, which is why it doesn't count), to the odd chronology of the standards being set "decades ago" somehow being counted against them, to the characterizing of Salazar's commonsense statement as "surprising", the author makes all the best arguments for Boston times not being counted as world records while seemingly trying to make the opposite point.It was a great race, the fastest ever run on a storied course, and for anyone who follows running that's plenty good enough.As the author points out, courses and conditions vary so much from marathon to marathon, comparing them is somewhat senseless.There's nothing wrong with just accepting that idea rather than seeing the exclusion of Boston times from world record consideration as somehow being an injustice.
